ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Overall, the teaching assistant for this course was accessible, organized, and able to explain concepts clearly and thoroughly.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Please identify the teaching assistant with whom you interacted most closely _____________________ .
comments: David Kneas
David Kneas
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David Kneas
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David Kneas
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  The TA is very nice and helpful.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  is a dude.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David Kneas
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David Kneas
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David was an amazing person to work with.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David Kneas
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David was the only teaching assistant in the course and he was very helpful
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David Kneas

Instructor: David Michael Kneas  (the question asks me to identify the TA, not to give an opinion of... but I presume that's why the text box is here?)David Kneas was a great TA, of course being more approachable since he was a MOD coordinator and therefore had a pre-existing rapport with students.

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: David Kneas is an amaaaaaazing TF!!!
Great class, but at times difficult to relate how topics and tensions discussed inform policy work (in other words, brought many questions to surface, but very few answers, so hard to contextualize).
The instructor gives lectures that are very well thought and very valuable, but the way he talks is a little plain so it's easy to feel sleepy...

I would consider seriously, if asked, to permit the possibility that Professor Dove is from the future, traveling backward through time Merlin Style, to help the people of the present prepare their thought for the problems of tomorrow.It is a privilege to hear his incisive questions, which have expanded my understanding of knowledge, power, and development.This class, although slow at times, was a tour of a remarkable array of historical and contemporary thought on the politics of development and knowledge of the environment.I am personally more interested in epistemology than international development, and feel that the course could have been focused even more towards this side. It did not necessarily provide a cohesive history of anthropological thought on environmental issues.the readings were fascinating, although often too substantial and numerous to be practical.The format for the class was partially great and partially challenging. See more below.

Question 7) There were no field trips. Field trips could have been an interesting addition to the learning process--for me variety in learning material, variety in class structure and variety in environment can all serve to spark creativity in thought and process. That would be my main recommendation for future classes--seek to integrate just a little more variety and experimentation into these 3 areas...I'm not suggesting that there wasn't variety--there was for sure, but maybe we just needed 10% more--especially with class structure--it seemed like students needed a little more prompting to feel comfortable to experiment and take ownership over seminar and to feel comfortable in structuring it in less conventional ways.It seemed like seminar could have been more productive if it were structured differently at times; perhaps smaller groups so that more people felt comfortable talking and sharing--especially the international students. There were fellow classmates who I barely heard from all semester. It might be nice if 2 or 3 seminars over the course of the semester were deliberately structured very differently from the rest. Also, it might be interesting to experiment with having 2 seminar sessions per week---perhaps shorter in length, but just as a test run to see if students like having a little more time for processing and reflecting on the material together.Perhaps at the beginning of the semester there could be a little bit of time for students to go around the room and share ideas for how to structure seminar--preferences, ideas, expectations. This might provide the impetus for student-initiated experimentation and seminar leadership later on in the semester. It seems important that students know they are encouraged to be creative and take ownership over their learning experience.Overall, great class.

Question 3 and 4: The workload (ie - the readings) were sometimes heavy making the following week's lecture seem to go by very quickly if one did not thoroughly read all the material. In one or two lectures I felt a bit lost but not because of the instructor's teaching style but because I could not complete all the readings or look through the supplemental material.
This is a foundation course and the best experience to be in Prof. Dove's class

Question 1: The readings certainly represent a heavy workload, and I know no one who actually read all of them - which is a pity. Would omitting certain extraneous chapters from some of the longer readings (books) be an option? This would ensure students are actually reading the most important parts of the assigned works...Question 2: There should be more clarity on the demands for the commentaries. That was unclear, especially since the guidelines in the syllabus weren't followed by fellow students, and there seemed to be no repercussions of that. Further, there should be clearer guidelines about student discussion leaders and expectations for discussion portions of class.Question 10: I wished for more conceptual explanations. I thought the texts were seminal works for reasons that weren't quite emphasized or explained enough in class. I felt it was easy for us to "gloss over" important concepts especially in class discussions.Question 11: The instructor errs on the side of being TOO responsive to student comments, especially ones that detract from or derail the discussion. He's the expert, so I wanted more decisive treatment of class discussion for optimal mastery of the concepts.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Professor Dove and David Kneas. Professor Dove provides incredible material in his lectures; I always walk away feeling like I have learned a lot. Also, Professor Dove's deadpan humour keeps me entertained very much.David adds a great deal to the discussion and is very available for his students. I love having his thoughts bounced back at me when I have questions.
The issue areas are thought provoking and readings are difficult but worthwhile. Guest lecturers were a plus.
The critical thinking is the best thing I learned from this class. You will begin to think in a totally different way than before.
In depth applied research project.Interesting readings and discussions.Futuristic, theoretical vibe.
Great material, great people, great ideas.
The selected readings provided a thorough introduction for understanding the intersection between anthropolgy and environmental issues.

1) professor Dove's teachings through his practitioner stories and careful listening to student's questions.2) David's availability at any time via email or office hours2.5) The readings are an amazing resource and are all very interesting.3) Commentaries on ClassesV2 for everyone to read.

The student-led presentations about the material, e.g. when commentators made powerpoints about their material. These were a good way to make the oftentimes dense and confusing reading material more approachable and understandable.
The interpretative thinking of the professor was unlike any other. It helped me look what otherwise would look common knowledge and information through a completely different lens.
The course provides an excellent overview of basic concepts in social science, which is essential to deal with many environmental problems.

Lecture. I definitely enjoyed and learned most from the lecture portions. Also, the weeks I was assigned a commentary I did a much better job synthesizing and learning the material, and found that I actually enjoyed doing them. (So perhaps a move to commentaries due every week would encourage better universal mastery of the concepts?)

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: More time needed for discussion. Also, clearer expectations on the style and substance of the writing assignments and discussion format would be helpful up front.Perhaps have more built-in assignments related to the term paper, such as an outline deadline, peer-review process, and outside group discussions. This would have helped my thinking and writing processes, as I struggled to tie everything together in a meaningful way.
Instructions to the readings... Readings are too much and too difficult for a beginner, so if there is any short introduction to each class's readings it would be great.

Slow....sometimes. While the pace was a nice counterpoint to the frantic scramble, it was sometimes dreary: Professor Dove reading a lecture sitting down, people just typing on their computers, or playing on facebook, lights off...etc. at the end of a full day, I wanted to run and jump and argue. The lectures themselves were amazing, but the format was sometimes hard for me to physically be fully present for.Luckily, I did get to do this occasionally in the discussions, which followed the lectures.I think the discussion leader format could be improved. People were sometimes confused, and we often reverted to the TA or Professor moderating.
See question 15
Maybe streamline the reading list for each week. Personally I rather thoroughly read fewer papers each week than glance at a couple more in preparation for each lecture.
The lecture part. This part of the class would often run over time, leaving less time for discussion.
The course is foundational and mainly relies of unique reading materials which are a bit outdated. Integrating new thoughts through up to date materials would add more value to the course
Reading load could be reduced little bit.

Student-led discussions. I found them generally to be a waste of time, since they were easily derailed and generally dominated by the same few individuals. Mechanisms should be implemented to minimize that, and ensure that we stay on the topic and are actually getting a deeper understanding of the material in the discussions. Otherwise, the discussions are a pointless aspect of the course.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: I'm not very sure the way to be a commentator, and the discussion is often dominated by few people...If more instruction could be put into how to write and organize the commentaries and discussions it will be better.

I would say for discussion that fewer discussants taking a more lead role in moderating would be ideal. It would also be great if people actually read the material and had strong opinions about it, but what can you do....I think to this end, slightly fewer readings, or even more prioritization, with required responses weekly from everyone with less polish would be more suitable to engaging people in the discussions.
See question 15

Very effective! Could be improve by having the commentators for each week ask the questions and let the class discuss possible answers. It seemed to me that in a lot of cases the commentators would simply talk about their point of view and since there were 5 to 8 commentators each week then the discussion period would just fly by without many other comments from the class.At some point a few students were talking about the idea of having a couple more discussion groups given that the class is so large and there are many commentators. More groups may mean smaller sizes and more opportunity for every student to voice an opinion or comment.
More time for discussion would be preferable, in my opinion.
Class lectures were always followed by group discussion sessions. This was effective in terms of creating a forum for student to learn from each other. I gained a lot from other students' experience.
It was effective.
See above.

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: David was phenomenal. He was super engaged, gave great feedback, and really was a valuable presence in discussions and in the paper writing process. There was a slight reliance on pop culture references towards the beginning of the class that I was n't totally into. Also, he maintains an awareness of class dynamics, but I would love to see much more emphasis in general, for everyone, placed on facilitation, and hearing multiple perspectives. Sometimes voices were overshadowed in practice, and I think David or Professor Dove could do more to set some precedent for totally inclusive discussions.
David was very supportive and organized.

Strength: good availability, always prepared for lecture and to answer questions, very helpful when brainstorming paper topics'weakness': From the one commentary session I had with David the only thing I noticed is that the discussion while it had important take away points of the general topic for the week we did not discuss the readings much.

Instructor: David Michael Kneas  TF was available to answer questions and talk through any issues. Expectations around writing assignments, discussion facilitation, and level of feedback could have been more targeted and specific.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  EXCELLENT teaching assistant - really attentive. Cares a lot about student work.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David is very helpful. He is very willing to instruct students in discussions and the paper.

Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David was a very positive presence in the class. He is very calm, straightforward and helpful. He was accessible when needed, sincere in his desire to help, and a great resource overall. He was great as both a source of moral support for a new grad student trying to get bearings in the program, and also as a fellow scholar offering suggestions, perspectives and academic resources to engage with. I will miss him!
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David was a great TF. He was always very approachable in and out of class, and he provided a lot of help with the course material and assignments in his office hours.

Instructor: David Michael Kneas  David was very positive, helpful and approachable. He was accessible to students anytime of the week. I also liked the way he was facilitating the group discussion sessions.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  I think David is very knowledgeable and is able to conduct the discussion sessions very well.
Instructor: David Michael Kneas  Likewise needed to be more demanding of the students in the discussion portions.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: I needed an introductory anthropology course to prepare for interdisciplinary work.
Provides a critical social science framework to my work ininternational sustainable development.
Anthropology is not my priority, but it could help me in my thought in conservation and people in future research and future work.

It was a fantastic counterpoint to my ecology heavy workload, and offered a chance to deal with theory, and also practice, by tapping into some real New Haven community processes in my final paper.I was super glad to take this class when I did, and it will certainly inform my subsequent work.

This course is foundational for the work I want to do--it is strongly related to my academic background (liberal arts/cultural studies/social sciences), and was very helpful in solidifying my continued interests in these areas while also showing me the potential of how to bridge disciplines.

I wish I took this course my first semester at F&ES considering that the lectures on Social Science research methods had great information and tips. I really enjoy the topic of anthropology and so this course fits well with my new found admiration for the subject.
The course does not directly fit with my overall program (which is now focused on climate change adaptation, communication, and education).

This course directly fits into my background. Anthropological view to the human environment interaction iswhat this course was all about. my background was Anthropology and I worked in natural resources management projects. This course had given me a whole lot of new insights on how to think as researcher,development practitioner or academician.
I needed an overview of social science concepts and the course was successful in achieving that objective.
See below (#21)

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I needed an introductory anthropology course to prepare for interdisciplinary work.
To expand theoretical methods and framework for international development work.
I would like to try some social science courses.
It fits into my program very well. I never had any anthropology background and it helped get a better perspective on development and interventions.
I was fascinated by Michael Dove and wanted a background in anthropology of the environment.
I was interested in the material, but probably more so I wanted to work with Professor Dove.
To get a basic sense for the literature available on social ecology.
To be able to look at my research materials and topic for the term paper.I ended up doing some of this but mainly re-examining my self and my goals (which was also very helpful but a bit scary).
Because I thought I might be interested in doing a research project in the summer, and this course offered me a way to explore whether that would be a good fit for me.
It was a required foundational course and I needed to learn from Prof Dove so that I gain some of the thinking dimensions in the larger human-environment interaction
To get an overview of social science concepts
Took the course as a substitute for Amity's qualitative research methods. Happy that it afforded me the insight and guidance of Professor Dove for my research proposal.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes
The readings and lectures were great. Discussions and writing assignments were a bit unsatisfactory (difficult to know how to improve).
Yes
I feel that my idea about the subject is still a little vague, no theories, concepts.... but maybe that is the feature of this class. I got a new angle to think about the same topics.

Yes and no. I learned a lot that I had no idea existed: always a good thing. I felt it did not offer a totally grounded overview of the field. I don't necessarily know key thinkers or schools of thought: I got a great sense of Dove's perspective, which is totally valued, but would like more context.I was more into the epistemological and cultural anthropology questions than endlessly problematizing development.
I am unsure of the role that anthropology will hold for me as I continue to do international community work, but gaining fluency in the literature was a rewarding experience.

I definitely learned a lot from this class and it did meet my expectations. Again, I could have learned more if I have done all the readings for each week instead of focusing on 3 and skimming the rest.
yes.
This course definitely met my expectation, I gained a lot
Yes
Yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: I loved doing a partnered response. It helped me learn more and was more fun, if less academic.
What I refer as work group are the group discussion sessions I had with other students after each class lecture. It was very advantageous to share views of other students.
N/A

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Do it! And start the paper early, likeProfessor Dove always says (and it almost never happens)

For anyone in the international development field, you should definitely take this course. You must, however, commit to doing the weekly readings, which can be a bit dense/esoteric, because that's how you will get the most benefit from the class.
Begin the readings early during the week, not the day before submitting your commentaries... Don't expect you can finish all of the readings, be realistic.

Just get prepared to read a lot and also try reading beyond the course materials to get a better understanding. However, only if you have ample amount of time because the course material already has a lot of readings listed.
Do it.
Take good notes during lecture, re-read your notes, give yourself time to process, think, reflect on what you are learning. Stay open.

Be sure to manage the time you devote to the class readings so that you can dedicate a portion of your reading time to articles for your final paper. Use the beginning of the semester to skim all of the required readings, then go back to specific readings for each class.

Start your papers in October!!!!!!! Maybe November at the latest. If you are doing Social Science Research, pay close attention to the research methods lectures.Talk to professor Dove often, he is great at sorting out topics and other questions.
Talk to the professor or the TF beforehand to try to find out whether the course is in fact a good fit for you (I found the course description to not be too helpful in that regard).
This is one course worth taking. I personally recommend it.
I think its an excellent course to get an overview of basic concepts in social science and application in dealing with environmental issues.
